question: Who or what was Big John de Conquer?
answer: Big John de Conquer was a legendary African American folk hero celebrated in the oral storytelling traditions of the Muck workers. He was described as a larger-than-life figure, 'a man dat wuz more'n man,' who embodied strength, defiance, and supernatural abilities. According to the tales told by the 'flame-throwers' (storytellers), Big John de Conquer did everything big on earth, then went up to heaven without dying, played guitar for the angels around God's throne, won a flying race to Jericho against everyone except God and Old Peter, went down to hell, beat the devil, and passed out ice water to everyone there. He was also characterized as someone who 'wouldn't dig potatoes, and he wouldn't rake hay: He wouldn't take a whipping, and he wouldn't run away' - representing resistance to oppression and enslavement. The character represents the spirit of resilience and triumph in African American folklore.
quote: Most of the great flame-throwers were there and naturally, handling Big John de Conquer and his works. How he had done everything big on earth, then went up tuh heben without dying atall. Went up there picking a guitar and got all de angels doing the ring-shout round and round de throne. Then everybody but God and Old Peter flew off on a flying race to Jericho and back and John de Conquer won the race; went on down to hell, beat the old devil and passed out ice water to everybody down there.
